categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Dairyopoly
description:
A modification of Monopoly. Instead of Atlantic City streets, players purchase dairy farms. When a monopoly is achieved, instead buying houses and hotels, players can buy calves and cows. Instead of jail, players can be sent to dairy school. And instead of rail roads, we have milk routes.

Anyone who likes Monopoly will probably like Dairyopoly. And anyone who likes Monopoly and is interested in dairies or cows will love it.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Trading

name: Stop-Over Frankfurt
description:
Stop-Over Frankfurt has two modes of play. In the first mode, players assume the roles of reporters who are trying to get an exclusive scoop of UFO sightings in the city of Frankfurt, Germany.

Each player is assigned a color and a transmission tower. Their goal is to transport photographs of extraterrestial visitors at locations in the city to their towers (transmitting the scoop back to their news agencies). Each player starts with one photo card, and take turns to roll a die, moving their card by the die's result. They draw new photo cards on a "6". The reporters can deploy Stop Stones to stop other reporters from moving through. The first reporter to transmit back three photographs wins the game.

The second mode of the game is called Top Secret, which is played on the other side of the game board. The game takes place in the news agency and players are racing against time to dig out what the others know. Each player thinks up a secret word at the start. On their turn, they roll a die, move their marker by the result, and can ask another player for one letter of their word. Players get points for guessing another player's secret word (which then has to be thought up anew). The game ends when one player's marker reaches the end point and the winner is the player who has the highest score.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Castle Quest
description:
From a review by Rick Heli, Spotlight on Games:

The game comes in a long box with a board, five decks of cards, a number of plastic chips in four colors representing gold pieces, six plastic pawns and a die.

The board is a circular track of thirty-four spaces with a depiction of a castle within it. In the castle are twelve labeled castle sections (drawbridge, six towers, king's court, dungeon, kitchen, rosengarden and dining hall) which players will try to own -- denoted by holding a card with the corresponding name.

Players all begin on the Start space with fifty gold pieces and roll the single die to move forward. Landing on a castle section allows buying that section, or, if it is already owned, forces payment of half the purchase price to the owner. Costs range from six to the most expensive section, the Drawbridge, which costs twenty. No section may be purchased until the Drawbridge has been. Other spaces on the board force drawing a card from one of three available decks which may have a cost to use: Move (free) moves the player to another space; Give (costs two) has various positive and negative effects; Receive (costs two) is similar to Give; Wishing Well (costs ten) has various effects including the Key to the Royal Bedroom. No one can win without the Key card. In addition, it is necessary to own at least half the castle sections.

Other spaces on the board force payment of tax, placed in the center of the board, or the chance to claim all the collected taxes. There are also three Flogging spaces where the player must either pay ten to avoid the flogging and take another turn or else roll a single die and risk going to the Dungeon. Players in the Dungeon languish there until another player is sent to the Dungeon, at which point they pay the new player one gold and resume play. The only other spaces on the board are one each to pick a player to lose a turn and to choose a player to be sent to the Dungeon.

name: Merits: A Growing Up Game
description: Players move through board meant to simulate a middle class life, earning merits for good deeds and losing merits for bad behavior. Players must make a couple of choices which path to take -- Public or private school; College, Military or Get a Job. Along the way you can opt to draw a card rather than accept the merits that a space offers you and you can get a companion that will add or subtract merits from you total for several turns. The goal is to reach the center space "Successful Adult Living" with the most Merits.

name: Tattletale Card Game
description: Based on the best-selling book "The Conversation Piece". Guess how your family, friends, and colleagues have responded to a wide range of questions. Ages 8 and up. Includes 240 full-color cards, special die, score pad, and rule booklet.

name: Welt 97
description:
A unique collectible "stickerstripgame" with an epic fantasy background story, W97 is a new type of game for two players of ages 10+, which combines collecting and pasting of stickers with unusual game mechanisms. In W97, players put together different sets of heroes, places, spells, victory conditions and much more based on a large supply of available stickers. The game is played on "terrain strips", which are divided into five quadratic fields next to each other, where the stickers are placed.

Every player puts together an individual place- and hero-set for a game of W97. A place-set is made up of six terrain strips Forest, Water, Desert, Swamp, Mountains and Grassland, where the stickers of tower, ruin, castle, city, cave and temple, that have to be conquered, with different amount of points on them, individually are pasted on.

A hero-set is put together of different heroes, representing the leaders of each player's armies (which are available in the game as small colored wooden cubes, that are placed next to the strips), who have to be distributed among the six terrain strips as well.

In W97 no general victory conditions are available for both players. Each player must setup the best fitting victory conditions for their places and heroes in their own game-sets themselves.

Success and failure in W97 is determined by a well put together game-set, the strategy of the player and the overall luck of dice rolls.

New players will find an easy and fast introduction into W97 through the basic set, which comes with pre-configured, presorted strips for two players. It is even not necessary to paste stickers onto the terrain strips, because all places and heroes already have been printed together with the terrain types in advance. In addition the basic game includes 6x60 wooden cubes, five color dice, a German and an English rulebook each and a randomly chosen Expansion-Set.

(Based on information from Wassertal Spieleverlag.)
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Modular Board, Tile Placement

name: Masquerade Party
description:
Players have to identify the celebrities based on the clues provided and by asking questions. Pictures of sixteen celebrities wearing heavy disguises are included the rule indicate more were available from the publisher through mail order.

The game is based on a then-popular television series.

name: Government-Funded Robot Assassins from Hell!
description: Clearly a very small-release inside joke, in this game players use their Robot Assassins in a race to earn 100 points by killing "various targets." The various targets include figures from the gaming industry such as Steve Jackson, Gary Gygax, Mike Stackpole, Richard Garfield, and the games' own designer (sadly, I don't see a target card for Reiner Knizia). Each player starts the game with a "Plain Bot" and may spend points to change the model of the Robot Assassin. Play is a simple matter of using cards to benefit assassins and targets and rolling dice to overcome modified target values. Game includes dice small enough that you could accidentally inhale them.

name: The Voyage of The First Fleeters: 1787-1788
description: This is supposedly a historical game about the British colonization of Australia. Be the first to successfully transport your ship of convicts from Portsmouth, England and set up a colony in Sydney, Australia. Take on provisions for the voyage and sail the high seas. Published in Australia by John Sands. Made in 1986
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Gizzajob
description:
"An exciting game of skill and chance as you make your way through the ups & downs of employment & unemployment to the ultimate Golden Handshake.

"The winner of the game is the first player to achieve 'THE GOLDEN HANDSHAKE AWARD,' or in the event of no player achieving this, the winner is the player with the most money. This is to be achieved by each player successfully completing either of their chosen career paths, each having its own pitfalls, and thus accumulating enough money to go for 'THE GOLDEN HANDSHAKE AWARD'."

name: Eyecatcher: Junior Edition
description:
From the publisher:

Eyecatcher Junior challenges kids to match game tiles to the gameboard. First, all the tiles are turned face down and then kids race against the timer to place as many tiles on the symmetrical board as possible. The tiles may look simple, but are designed around unique animal pairs that will test children's identification and motor skills. At the end of each player's turn, the total number of tiles placed correctly on the board are counted and recorded on the unique score sheet. Kids can play as many rounds as they want and best of all the game cannot be mastered since each turn presents a completely new challenge. Eyecatcher Junior encourages kids to concentrate carefully while acting quickly and they have lots of fun doing it!

name: Sports Challenge for Kids
description:
From the publisher:

I'm a real swinger, I help Mac attack, and my barrel is not full of oil. Am I Babe Ruth's glove, Mark McGuire's bat, or a marksman's pistol? Kids play tabletop versions of soccer, basketball, and tennis, and test their sports knowledge in four fun categories. Covers a wide range of sports, from football to field hockey, and from baseball to bicycling. It's easy to learn and fun to play. If you love sports, then you'll really get into the game!

name: The Prospector Game
description: According to Sid Sacksons "A Gamut of Games": A simple mystery is set up by removing a "prospector" and a "strike" card from a set of eight. Players land on spaces that allow them to pick up cards and also to question opponents about cards they hold.

name: Shrink
description:
From Sid Sackson's A Gamut of Games:

Not a competitive game, but rather an opportunity for self-discovery. Forty-seven cards have pictures of various animals, objects, styles, etc. Players choose those that fit them, that they'd like to be, or not to be.

name: Danmark trivia game
description: In Danmark trivia game you have 400 cards with 2400 questions from six categories : Miscellaneous, History, Sport, Culture, Nature and Geography. All questions concern Danmark only. Collect a token from each category to win. The players roll a die to move and then they must answer a question from the category they land on. If they answer correctly they get a token and when they've gathered tokens in every colour, they can head to the capital (center). First they need to get to a corner of the board where they answer a question of their own choosing. Then there are two coloured spaces from the corner to the center. When the players get to the center they answer a question of the other player(s) choosing. A correct answer in the center means victory!

name: Kunnskapsspillet Jackpot
description: Traditional trivia game.

name: Langrenns-VM
description: Cross-country skiing game. Choose any distance between 5 and 50 KM, but be sure to pick the right equipment because the conditions might change during the course.

name: Hoppin' Checkers
description: This is a simple checkers game for children featuring the Disney characters Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck. The board is a 7x7 grid of squares with 5 Rock spaces (where your pieces start) at each end, and Lily Pad spaces in the middle. These are checkered by River spaces that cannot be played on. You must get your 5 Mickey or Donald pieces to the rock on the other side of the river. Play is like regular checkers, but you cannot make multiple jumps. An advance game introduces Frogs which are neutral pieces that can be moved to block board spaces. The first player to cross the river with all his or her pieces wins.

name: Zyklopen & Katakomben
description: The players try to kill cyclops and monsters in ancient Greece. Besides monster-hunting you can work to earn money and buy equipment for better hunting.

name: Föräldrafritt med Bert
description:
"Without parents with Bert"

A teen game dealing with the event that we all remember from our younger days as both dreadful and desirable at the same time - the school disco! Play as Bert or one of his five friends; as an old-fashioned gender specific game, boy pieces start from Åke's Video Couch while girl pieces start from Nadja's Bathroom, and there are actually cards in the game that work differently depending on what the player's real gender is. You'll first need to make your way to the disco which is easier said than done, with Komplex cards making your life difficult at every turn with things like pimples, clothes that are out of fashion or runny mascara; then make your way past the bouncer to actually get inside; then battle your way through the Necking cards with various good and bad events, with the ultimate goal of getting to do a slow piece with the girl/boy you fancy; to finally succesfully resolve a Last Dance card in order to win the game.

Based on the comic strip FF med Bert which itself is based on the series of teen books of the same name as the game, and following the life of the Swedish teenage boy Bert.

name: Astrocards
description:
From the publishers website:
With Astrocards the players will discover the exciting world of astrology. How does the stars effect your life and that of your friends and family.

name: Lowe's Horse Racing Game
description:
4 1/2 x 4 1/2 x 7/8 Maroon 'leatherette' box made to look like a small book. Spine has silver 'Horse Race', 'VOL. 534', and 'E.S.Lowe'.

Contents include a 'cribbage-like' board with 6 numbered lanes, each lane is 14 straight spaces long, 6 numbered paper cards with individual historic horse names, 6 small colored pegs that look like tiny chess queens in a small slide-out tray, and 3 wooden six-sided dice.

No rules were included but the 'obvious' play is to select a numbered horse in the field of 6. Roll the 3 dice and then move each numbered horse up the track the number of spaces that its number comes up on the dice. Holes are drilled to allow placement of Win, Place, and Show pegs.

name: Befri prinsessen
description:
From the box:
Can you avoid the dangers and be the first to rescue your princess?

name: Hvornår var det nu det var?
description: Trivia game were the players try to guess the year in which an event happened in the period between 1960 and 1996.

name: Mästerdetektiven
description:
From the Box:
Who is the mysterious thief in professor Petterson's house?
The exciting game where you will get a chance to try your detective skills.

name: Auto Race
description: This simple track game was released in 1928 as part of a four-game set including Ludo (i.e. Pachisi), Checkers, and Backgammon. The board depicts a colorful racetrack with illustrated obstructions. On your turn, you roll a die and move ahead the number indicated. There are five obstructions on the track, such as "REPLENISH OIL" etc., representing two spaces, all of which must be jumped in the progress of the game. If your roll would land you on an obstruction, you lose your turn instead. The first player to circle the track and cross the Finish Line wins.

name: Min häst
description: Children's game were the players take care of horses.

name: King of Tarts
description:
Pucker up and play by drawing and discarding sequential sets of cards to win tokens. Can you be the first to collect 6 identical Sour Power Tokens and win?
52 card deck and 80 sour power tokens.

name: Pin High
description:
Simple Australian card game based on a 9 or 18 hole round of golf. There is no course (and no board), though players try to match the par scores for various well known courses (Augusta, Muirfield, Pebble Beach, Royal Melbourne, Royal Sydney and St Andrews).

Cards depict distances and various clubs including drivers, irons, putters, pitching wedges, "Lost Ball" various "Traps", and few nice ones like "Holed Approach", "Holed Putt".

name: Camping, Hiking & Outdoor Trivia
description:
Contains thousands of questions on camping, hiking, national and state parks, forest, memorials and trails, RVing, first aid, wilderness survival, campgrounds, fishing, mountain biking, Boy and Girl Scouts, camping food, camping gear, campfire songs, stories, wildlife conservation and much more.
The object of the game is to answer the questions correctly and acquire a colored token in each of the 5 categories.

name: Get the Picture
description: Using the pictorial clues found in the cartoon drawings, players must correctly guess the name of the personality or group depicted in each game card. Card categories include: Hollywood, Music, Sports, and Famous People. Each correct answer earns a roll of the die to advance the player token along the game board.

name: Intimate
description:
From the box. "The object for the game is for players to move forward and towards the center of the board, to enter the Erogenous zone, and ultimately to enter the Hot zone. When two players are in the small confines of the Hot zone at the same time this is considered to be the end of the game, as the excitement and the stimulation gained and given, in order to achieve this position, will make further concentration difficult,- if not impossible for anything other than making love, which is the real object of the game."

"Players movements throughout the game are determined by the way they respond to either of three types of instructions read from cards picked at random. They could be asked to answer a question, do a forfeit, or perform an action, all of which are designed to stimulate all the senses and to prepare and encourage the players to bring the game to a satisfactory conclusion."

name: Lyle's Baseball Game
description:
In 1991, Sheryl and Steve Shrout took one of Steve's old game ideas and worked it into an actual game product. The game, "Lyle's Baseball Game", draws its identity from Steve Shrout's middle name. It may be played solo or with two players. While the game is essentially a dice rolling contest, there are some amusing rules tossed in:

- No kicking dirt onto home plate.
- No spitting on the field.
- All rolls of the dice are final. No arguing with the dice.
- Seventh inning stretch optional, but suggested for couch potatoes.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Point to Point Movement

name: Counterterrorist
description:
15mm tabletop game owing a nod to computer games like Rainbow 6 and Counterstrike. Comes in a box with 11 miniatures, one 128-page book (the rules are about 14 pages - the rest is lists and background), two dice and a tape measure.

The heart of the game is an action point system with straight d10 rolls used to resolve actions. Combat is a lengthy process where you have to hit, wound and beat an armor save (yes, it's Warhammer 40k all over again) and then see what injury you delivered. Armor and injury saves are not modified by weapons, so whether you took a hit from a derringer or an anti-material rifle makes no difference to the target - a rather silly outcome, but there you have it.

There is a point buy system, a lengthy compendium of weapons & equipment (many of them with quite unrealistic stats) and a number of light vehicles (civilian models primarily - no tanks or APCs).

name: StarMarines
description:
If you've ever been intrigued by that game of futuristic land combat by a company whose name rhymes with "Hames Nerkslop," but were put off by the cost of figures or the time and skill needed to paint them, this game might be just the ticket. Instead of expensive figures, you use free downloadable counters. Instead of a large gaming table filled with hand-made scenery, you use my M8 maps. If you want a bigger army or a larger map, just download another page and print it. Time-consuming movement and combat rules have been replaced with fast-playing hex-based rules. And all the occult stuff in the original game has been replaced with... nothing at all.

If you're unfamiliar with that game, the premise is straightforward: buy soldiers, vehicles and weapons with the build-points given to you, then fight an enemy of a different alien race. You can also "buy" experience or special skills for your troops, or add a Hero if you think he will help. Some races excel at crunching close combat, while some prefer a fast-moving style; some fight in low-tech swarms, and others prefer high-tech gadgets. Vehicles range from one-man scout bikes to hulking super-tanks. The size of the battle can be a squad of foot soldiers, or a company of 150-plus men with dozens of vehicles, or anything in between. Several basic scenarios are provided with the rules. Almost everything is definable.


StarMarines is a Free game based off of War Hammer 40,000
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Hexagon Grid, Modular Board

name: Silly Stories
description:
From the box back.

Perfectly sensible sentences get wacky fast when they're scrambled into crazy combinations.

In an original twist on memory card games, kids flip story cards to hunt down the WHO, WHAT, and WHERE that combine to tell a Silly Story.

Simpler and more challenging ways to play give beginners and veteran players alike plenty of brain building fun.

Learning the Silly Stories way...

Pre-readers and early readers alike have fun while they practice their memory skills, word recognition, powers of observation and giggles.

name: The Wright Brothers
description:
From the publisher:
"The Wright Brothers has you travel the path of discovery that led to one of the greatest triumphs of technology — the invention of the airplane. If you’ve gained enough knowledge and experience, be the first to successfully fly the Wright’s airplane, the Flyer, on the sand dunes at Kitty Hawk."

name: His 'N' Hers
description:
HIS 'N' HERS - The Battle of the Sexes

From the Box:

"How well do you really know your partner? Or best friend (or best friend's partner?)
Well now is your chance to find out. You choose the subject, you choose the questions, analyze the points scored and then you'll find out (what you probably knew all along) if you're living with a Male Chauvinist Pig, a Right Wing Wet, a Left Wing socialist or just a plain slob. Yes you'll discover the real man or woman in your life."

Contents:
Booklet
Subject Cards
Prediction Cards
Bonus Cards

A questioner selects a subject (e.g. indulgences, work) and reads out the three character descriptions from the booklet, appropriate to the "interviewees" sex. The players (including the questioner and interviewee) then vote (using prediction cards) on which type of characteristics the "interviewee" exhibits.

The questioner then selects 6 questions from the Subject Cards corresponding to the subject chosen. The questioner then reads out the questions and three possible answers. Each answer scores either 1, 2 or 3 points depending on the response given by the interviewee - these points are noted down discretely by the questioner.

Once the six questions have been answered the points are totaled and the score related back to the character traits announced at the start of the round. The character of the interviewee is thereby determined.

Players that successfully predicted which character trait the interviewee would show score points. The winner is the player with the highest score after an agreed number of rounds.

name: Seaquest
description:
Seaquest: The Great Naval Strategy Game

The game of "SEAQUEST" is one of the most thrilling and intriguing games you will ever play. It is a contest of strategy, bluff and ingenuity for two players or two teams, which may be played by young children (from about 9 and upwards) as well as mature adults. "SEAQUEST" is an ideal party game, and popular with all people who appreciate good games of skill and enjoy the opportunity to exercise their wits and imagination. It is especially interesting when played by two groups or teams of players.

Seaquest is a simple game like Battleships with some ship-shaped miniatures and a board with a screen across the middle to allow secrecy.

name: Huff 'n Puff
description:
The object of this children's game is to be the last player with his house standing after the wolf has destroyed the other houses. Based loosely on the Big Bad Wolf children's story, each player has a pig inside either the straw, wood, or brick house.

At the beginning of the game, each player secretly drops a metal pin into one of the 12 holes belonging to the player to his left. Players use a spinner, taking turns to determine which player will be forced to place a plastic pin into one of the holes belonging to his house. If he is lucky, nothing happens and the pin remains in the hole. If he hits the hole in which his opponent has placed the secret metal pin, it will activate the wolf. The wolf will crash down into his house (which he assembled at the beginning of the game) destroying the house and exposing the pig inside. That player is then eliminated from the game.

name: I Want Candy!
description:
From the Invisible City Productions website:

All the fun of a pinata, with none of the screaming, accidental concussions, or clean-up. For two to six hyperactive greed-crazed kids (or kids at heart).

Object: To form specific combinations of cards by selecting them from a common pool of face-down cards.

Play is simple: Scatter a Poker deck face-down on your playing surface. Set a timer for one minute. Start the timer.

There are no turns; all players act simultaneously. Your goal is to search for the cards that you need (combinations and penalties are listed on printable reference cards) while abiding by the rules of the game (only use one hand, only hold one card at a time, move cards you want to your 6-card-max stash, move cards out of your stash that you don't want, and don't touch other players during the game.) All play stops when the timer rings. If you have a card in your hand when the timer rings, you’re stuck with it whether you want it or not.

Once play has stopped, reveal your stash. Compare your stash to the Combinations and Penalties reference cards. If you have the highest score, you win.

Download the rules and the reference cards here:
http://www.invisible-city.com/play/157/i-want-candy

name: Dino Dig
description:
From the Invisible City Productions website:

Search for specimens and toss mud on two to four paleontologists.

You’re a world-famous paleontologist. You’ve been commissioned by a prestigious museum to unearth and assemble a dinosaur. There’s a new dig site rich in fossils. Find the biggest dino!

Object:To gather specific sets of cards while placing useless cards where your opponents will find them.

The game is played on a 'dig site' made up of piles of playing cards. Each player has 3 paleontologists. The players move their paleontologists around the dig site looking for cards they can use to make dinosaurs (each card represents a portion of a dinosaur.) The game ends when one player has at least 5 cards in his 'museum' and has brought all of his paleontologists back to his home space. The player with the longest run (ex: 9-10-J-Q) of cards wins. Ties go to the run with the highest card in it.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Set Collection

name: Syntactics
description:
According to Sid Sacksons "A Gamut of Games":

Word tiles are played as sentences along a recessed path winding toward the center of the board. Crossing sentences can be entered at ten indicated locations.

name: Kung Fu Challenge
description: Probably a promotional game. A card game of Kung Fu battle between The Crane, The Mantis, The Snake, The Tiger, The Toad and The Tortoise. Each player holds circular cards depicting the above creatures. Players compete each other with the Rock, Paper, Scissors mechanics.

name: CEO: Corporate Entities & Oddities
description:
Game by a company that specializes in publishing business books and self-study courses.

CEO is essentially a trivia game for business students and business history buffs. Many questions are specific to the time-period (1984), which makes answering them tricky at best and eye-rollingly impossible at worst.

The object of the game is to move up the corporate ladder from Entry Level to the CEO position. To accomplish this, players answer questions in categories like Slogans and Trademarks, Crimes and Blunders, Media, and others. Each correct answer earns the player performance review slips, which are collected (along with another correct answer, this time to a special Promotion question) to earn promotions to the next level. Each level requires a greater number of performance review slips to move ahead. If a player lands on a Pink Slip space, they may take away all the collected performance reviews of an opponent. The first player to be promoted to CEO wins the game.

Contents:


Game board
4 question booklets
Performance review slips
4 pawns
6-sided die
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Simulation

name: Think Twice
description:
Early trivia game from Reiss.

Game Objective: To be the first player to score 40 points. Instead of playing for 40 points, players may set a time limit (such as 1 hour) and the player with the most points at the end of that time is the winner. A time limit is preferable when a large group is playing.

name: Challenge Anneka
description:
CHALLENGE ANNEKA is a board game based on the BBC TV series of the same name in which presenter Anneka Rice is given a finite amount of time to complete a given task - this must be completed by persuading people to provide freely of their time, money and resources.

From the box:

"Take your challenge card, read it, make your way to a start location and you're off.

Now you have to race against time, and the other players to collect all the Joiners, Bricks, Printers, Florists, Pop Stars, Movie Stars ... and of course plenty of volunteers ... you may need to complete your challenge.

You can rush around the board visiting various locations to find Volunteers or use your trusty mobile phone to call any number in the telephone directory to collect the other items.

But remember that the other players are after the same things and the time is always ticking away!

You'll need all your wits about you to be the first player to complete the challenge."

name: Pink Elephant
description:
PINK ELEPHANT is an adults only drinking game which is, I quote, "Not intended for use with alcoholic beverages"!

From the box:

"Now you can get your parties really buzzing with this outrageous drinking game for 2-6 "sober" adult girls and boys.

Can you stagger round the board collecting Pink Elephants and doing the very, very silly things the cards demand?

Be prepared to submit yourself to appalling forfeits, answer embarrassingly ludicrous questions, and consume bladder bursting quantities of your chosen drink...all whilst trying to blow up the pink Elephant balloons.

The player with the strongest constitution, the smallest glass or the fewest inhibitions wins!"

Need I say more...?
publishers: Pass-out Games, Paul Lamond Games Ltd

name: Fraction
description:
A game of action. A game of fractions. FRACTION is a game of fun and learning. Players compete to complete the circle in this test of skill and challenge.

Game includes: 32 Fractional playing pieces, divided into 2 halves, 3 thirds, 4 quarters, 6 sixths, 8 eighths and 9 ninths, a number of Playing Rings, two dice, one marked with halves, quarters and thirds and the other marked with sixths, eighths and ninths.

Object of the game: To complete the most rings at game's end.

How to play:

Each player takes two rings from the kitty with all other rings and fractional pieces remaining in kitty. As the game progresses, a player, during his turn, may take another ring rom the kitty as long as rings remain. Players cannot take rings from other players.

Players in turn, roll the die. Players select the fractional piece that corresponds to the die roll and fits it to one of the two rings.

Play rotates clockwise with each player rolling and placing pieces. Play continues with players trying to complete a circle.

If a fractional part rolled on the die cannot be used, or does not want to use it, the player does nothing and play passes to the next player.

A player, during his turn, can move a fractional part from one uncompleted ring to another without penalty.

Play continues until all parts are used. Game ends at this point and the player with the greatest number of completed circles is the winner.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Pattern Building, Pattern Recognition, Set Collection

name: Taco Shop Psychic
description:
It’s lunchtime at the local taco shop, and the friendly neighborhood psychic is hungry. You happen to be on the clock when he places his order. He wants one of each food item on the menu – a taco, an enchilada, a burrito, a soft taco, a tostada, and a plate of nachos – and whoever fills his order fastest will get a year’s supply of psychic reading. Now the whole front line is scrambling to get the psychic what he wants. Taco Shop Psychic is all about rushing an order out as fast as you can… and keeping your co-workers from doing the same!

Be the first to fill the psychic’s taco shop order!

* Players: Three to six players
* Format: Card/Board game
* Play Time: 30 minutes or so...
* Included: Board, 152 cards, rules sheet
* Also Required: One pawn, to represent "The Psychic"

The game is published as a PDF.

name: Bulls Hit
description:
From the box:

"BULLS HIT is a fun game involving watching each others' flies as they zip in and out of their favorite cowpat. The first fly that's 'dungroamin' is the winner.

Each fly must start in the very bowels of the country pancake and then wind their way out again.

Dung - the final frontier. Set your flies in motion as you travel from the very heart of the 'dung-eon' of no return. No holes are barred in the windy city of flies.

You'll play this game until the cows come home!"

The aim of the game is to work your way out of the middle of the cowpat by telling stories or making statements convincingly enough to make your opponents guess wrongly as to them being Bulls-Hit, No Bulls-Hit or Total Bulls-Hit. The winner is the first player to get out of the cowpat.

name: Care Bears: How Many Bears?
description: How Many Bears is a children's card game about counting and color matching. Players turn over cards from their hand and try to match cards in the middle of the table by either color or number of bears on each card. The player who collects the most matches wins. Ages 4 - 8
categories: Children's Game, Movies / TV / Radio theme

name: Beat the Competition
description: In this game, you are a traveling sales person who is sent around the country trying to make sales. It is a basic roll and move game, with everyone choosing a different "home territory" (starting place). You must pay for expenses along the way, and the winner is the person who makes the most money.

name: Billy Goat
description: Children's game for Ages 4 - 10. Players take turns stacking blocks at the end of the playing surface. Eventually the weight of the blocks will cause the rubber-band loaded billy goat to launch into the wall of blocks, knocking them down. The player who was putting a brick on the wall when the billy goat was triggered is now out of the game. The goat is reset, and play starts over. The last player remaining wins.

name: California Wine Quiz
description:
Requires a knowledge of California wines. Comes in a wooden box which looks almost identical to Bowker's 'The Winery Game' .

The board consists of California wine maker labels, each numbered. Using the number, you look up questions in either the Odd Book or the Even Book. Points are scored based on the answers.

Includes:

1 Wood box w/slot for the game board.
1 full color, mounted game board which also acts as the sliding box top.
2 question books, about 80-pages each, 11-1/4" x 7-1/2"
1 pad of score sheets, 11" x 3-1/4"
4 Wine cork playing pieces, colored on top
1 6-sided die

name: Spin the Bottle: The Game for Girls
description:
From the publisher:

It’s the game of blushes and crushes! Learn about yourself and your friends when you play this sensational slumber party game. You’ll answer fun, funny “what if” questions and collect pictures of the boys you want to kiss. Don’t worry, they’re not real boys. They’re just on cards! Maybe you’ll kiss Computer Curt or Shy Shawn. Only the spinner knows… Comes with a spinner, punch-out tokens, instructions and 50 cards. Give it a whirl!

name: The Elvis Trivia Game
description:
From the Box:

A classic tribute to the King of Rock 'N' Roll.

Stroll down memory lane and relive some unforgettable moments in the celebrated life and career of Elvis. With beautiful photos and trivia from the '50s, '60s, and '70s, step into the life of the greatest superstar the world has ever known. Each game is numbered and contains a certificate of limited edition.

The object of the game is to be the first to collect a matching set of four Elvis photos by answering Elvis trivia questions.

name: Beware of the Spider
description: This sprightly spider dares players to reach into his web and capture legs to attach to their own spider. When a hand enters the web, the spider barks out a command. "Hey, you - give back this leg" or "You, take one leg from another player" are just a few examples. This is really a novelty game trying to combine some aspects of Cootie with sound and voice...

name: Who's Had Who?
description:
From the box:

"Who's Had Who? The Celebrity Gossip Game

"All the fun of after dinner seduction with none of the practical difficulty.

"Who's Had Who? the ultimate in after dinner entertainment, at least seven times funnier than getting drunk and falling asleep in an awkward position.

"A box full of hilarious gossip about the rich and famous together with the chance to play at seducing a host of celebrities from Ronald Reagan to Marilyn Monroe and Des O'Connor.

"Who's Had Who? contains over 1000 hilarious gossip questions, but these are just one element of the game. As in real life luck, skill, technique, wit, the possession of the right attributes and even the ability to induce a headache in Joan Collins so as to protect her from Warren Beatty, all play their vital part.

"Based on the best selling comedy book 'Who's Had Who' the game is devised by its authors and the inventor of the best-selling strategy game 'September'.

"Raucous, flirtatious and always good for a giggle, Who's Had Who? invites you to play with the largest range of celebrities ever available in one box."
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Bag
description:
psssst! Hey, buddy. What’s in the BAG?—- a creative thinking word game, minus the letters and words, for two or more players

Goal: To form a lattice of interlocking meme (a unit of cultural information that can be transmitted from one mind to another) strings.

You Need:


A set of BAG tiles. You can download, print, and cut apart our starter BAG tile set . We strongly recommend creating your own set or customizing the starter set. Just glue snippets from magazines onto the backs of the starter set tiles and trim the clipping to fit the tile.
A bag or other opaque container to put the BAG tiles in.
A flat surface to play on.


Each player draws seven tiles from the bag. On your turn, try to find a theme or concept that two or more of them share. One you’ve found a theme for one or more of your tiles, lay them in the play area. If tiles are already in play, the tiles you play must intersect one or more of them.

Draw one tile for every tile you played. Score one point for every tile in each meme-string you added to or created. Play passes to the left.

The first player with 21 points wins.
categories: Party Game, Print & Play, Word Game

name: Curious George Take It Away Game
description: The game includes 40 tiles (4 each of 10 scenes from Curious George books). The tiles are spread face-up on the table. One player removes a tile from the table while the other players close their eyes. Then the other players open their eyes and race to determine the missing piece. The first player to identify the missing piece scores a point. This is repeated until someone wins by scoring four points.

name: Let's Bowl A Game
description:
Roll a strike, pick up a spare or even make that split and "bowl over" your opponents. A challenging card game for any number of players. It gives scores comparable to actual bowling scores, yet gives you a better chance to attain that impossible dream - a 300 game.

Comes with 52 cards, score sheets, and instructions.

name: The Market Square
description:
THE MARKET SQUARE is one of a series of Monopoly style board game developed by local YMCAs in the UK to generate funds for their activities. The games in the series are essentially the same, but as in the different versions of Monopoly, the board and the businesses are specifically themed to the town or city represented in the title - in this case LISBURN in Northern Ireland.

Players progress around the board as a result of the roll of 2D6. When landing on a Company square a player may purchase a share in that company (there are two shares available in each company), if he wishes. If not he may put the share up for auction, with any excess over the sale price being retained by that player as his fee for being the auctioneer.

Players landing on companies that are already owned must pay to visit, with the payment due being based on how many shares are owned in that particular company and in the other two companies in the same colour series. Since shares can be owned by two different players both may demand payment from a visitor.

Certain squares on the board require the drawing of a Chance card which normally result in income being received from or paid to the bank.

The “New Share Quotations” square results in the changing of share prices for some of the blocks of companies. This will result in players losing or gaining money on the shares that they own. It also requires players to put up one of their shares for auction thereby permitting players to trade in shares.

The game can be ended in three ways, which should be decided before the game starts:
- After a set time.
- When the first player becomes bankrupt.
- When all but one player has gone bankrupt.

At the end of the game the money is counted and shares are valued at whatever is the then current rate. The player with the greatest assets is declared the winner.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Meganation
description:
Meganation is a fast-paced game of non-stop excitement as players attempt to dominate the world by acquiring all of its nations and as much money as possible. There is never a dull moment as players purchase, trade, barter, charge duty fees and initiate live auctions.

In this entertaining family game, players must guard their borders, avoid landing on unfriendly territory and build their empire to become a MEGANATION.
mechanics: Dice Rolling, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: The Wizard of Oz Returns
description:
The Wizard of Oz Returns (Game and Record)
Sid Frank/Ralph Stein
Golden Records

Amusing sequel to the Wizard of Oz complete with songs and voices that attempt to match the 1939 musical, but which follows neither the thread of the MGM film nor the book.

Simple Roll and Move game, significant in that game board is actually printed on a vinyl record sleeve.
categories: Dice, Fantasy, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Novel-based, Party Game
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Alfons Godnatt-spel
description: The character Alfons has a lot to do before going to bed. He must brush his teeth, read a book and much more. You must help him do all this so he can get to sleep.

name: Banana Republika
description:
Translation of German description:
The heads of big politics clash in their fight for power. Take over their role and show those other combatants who the real king of the hill is: use ministers, panels and the press to bully your opponents or to increase your own glory. Get your politicians into the government to create the stupidest and most senseless laws and to reserve your seat in the political cabinet of absurdities.
First shown at Essen 2005

name: B.C.opoly
description:
The Game Includes:

Tokens:
Alarm Clock, Pencil, Gym Shoe, Bicycle, Graduation Cap

Board Spaces:
MODS, Flynn Recreation Complex, Conte Forum, O'Neill Library, Gasson Hall

Cards:
Boston College vs. Notre Dame. Advance to Alumni Stadium. GO BC!

Middlemarch Ball! All tokens advance to O'Connell House.

Advance with the token of your choice to Pino's Pizza.
mechanics: Auction/Bidding, Dice Rolling, Player Elimination, Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection, Stock Holding, Trading
publishers: Late for the Sky Production Company

name: BrightonOpoly
description:
BRIGHTONOPOLY is concerned with business trade in Brighton. The object of the game is to accumulate as much wealth as possible through the purchase, trade and development of businesses - the businesses themselves representing actual firms on the Island or town.

It has the following features:

- Businesses to buy, trade and sell.
- A £500 ‘Loan Card’ for each player, ‘Get Out of Jail’ in another game.
- The ability (once you own all the key businesses in a colour group) to expand by building shops and superstores. Though you wouldn’t guess that from the counters!
- Magistrates Court - a place where you get sent when you have failed to pay your bills - though you are able to visit if you happen to pass by.
- The Baron Langham Square, where you gain £200 by passing through. Not in the usual position of one of the corner squares, but two squares after the Start.
- 21"Take A Break" and 21"Lets Go Bowling" cards.
- Mortgages
- Wheeler's of St.James. Sponsored Free Parking.

- ... and many more.

Box Description : Painting of Brighton Pier Titled: Its Never Too Late by Philip Dunn
Board Description : Picture of 3 deckchairs in front of the pier from the painting; More Vacant Places by Philip Dunn.
Year of Manufacture : 1998
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding, Trading

name: JerseyOpoly
description:
JERSEYOPOLY is concerned with business trade in Jersey. The object of the game is to accumulate as much wealth as possible through the purchase, trade and development of businesses - the businesses themselves representing actual firms on the Island or town.

It has the following features:

- Businesses to buy, trade and sell.
- A £500 ‘Loan Card’ for each player, ‘Get Out of Jail’ in another game.
- The ability (once you own all the key businesses in a colour group) to expand by building shops and superstores. Though you wouldn’t guess that from the counters!
- Mont Orgueil Castle - a place where you get sent when you have failed to pay your bills - though you are able to visit if you happen to pass by.
- The Leonidas Square, where you gain £200 by passing through. Not in the usual position of one of the corner squares, but two squares after the Start.
- 21"Pay & Take" and 21"Good News/ Bad News" cards.
- Mortgages
- Sapphire Bedrooms Sponsored Free Parking.

- ... and many more.

Box Description : Mont Orgueil Castle and Gorey Harbour, Jersey. Art: David Manby
Board Description : Mont Orgueil Castle and Gorey Harbour, Jersey.
Year of Manufacture : 1997
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Stock Holding, Trading

name: Steamy Scenes
description: Players (couples selected at random) act out "steamy scenes" from well known movies, for the audience to guess" A sexier version of "charades" combined with "amorous amateur dramatics" could describe this fun game which will bring out the ACTOR WITHIN. It provides the opportunity to bring a semblance of professional detachment to a scene that some would find sensual, arousing or downright embarrassing. The two acting partners selected at random have 3 minutes to convince the audience of the title of a movie, playing in silence the scene(s) as described in detail on the card. A further 3 minutes is allowed for "charades" type play if the acting is not up to it.

name: Contraption
description:
Contraption is a unique, motorized game from Lakeside. The game itself consists of 2 sets of colored marbles and a single unit with 4 gears on its surface. The gears are laid end-to-end, with the larger gears in the middle. Each player claims one of the smaller end gears as their "home" gear.

To play, the unit (requiring 2 "D" batteries) is turned on, which sets all 4 gears spinning. Then the marbles are dumped into the large central gears. Each player controls a switch that, when pressed, lowers a gate between their home gear and the larger gear, allowing marbles to pass through -- but also letting marbles pass back out to the larger gears.

The goal of the game is to be the first player to capture all 6 of your marbles in your home gear.
publishers: Action Games and Toys Ltd, Gay-Play, Lakeside

name: Scroll
description:
The board is 11 spaces square. The outer squares are not used except for the corner ‘home base’ squares. In the center is a 3 square x 3 square scroll zone, which includes four 'sleeping men'. Each player starts with nine counters. These may be moved either 1 or 4 squares each turn in a straight line in any direction but may not jump over any other pieces. Pieces are captured if they are sandwiched between two pieces of one other player of if the piece becomes the third piece in a diagonal formation. Captured pieces entitle a player to reclaim pieces previously lost.

There are three levels of winning. Basic - by eliminating all of your opponent's pieces. A scroll win - make the scroll zone entirely your color. A Grand scroll - make the scroll zone entirely your color, but without using your sleeping man.

name: Swipe
description:
The thrilling strategy game of high class, high risk, and high drama. Capture the most points in Diamonds, Gold, Jewels, and Money... .while avoiding being handcuffed.

Ages 8 and up and for 2 - 4 Players.

The object of the game is to be the "Swiper" who swipes the most cards and scores 1000 points first. Points are scored by swiping up combinations of cards through builds.

name: Bible Rummy
description:
(From the back of the box)

Bible Rummy
Jumbo Card Game

Now families with young children can enjoy this popular game with a spiritual bonus.

12 beautifully illustrated stories from the Bible
Jumbo-size cards are easy for little hands to hold and organize
No reading required
Set contains


48 brightly colored story cards.
1 instruction card with Bible story references
1 Faith Parenting card

name: Black Quest
description: Black Quest is a game designed to educate the player in the history of African-Americans. The game consists of a deck of question cards, a deck of bonus cards, a die, a tumbler, and a score pad. A turn consists of a players rolling the die, then answering the question from a question card corresponding to the number on the die. A roll of 6 allows the player to answer a question from the Bonus deck. The turn continues until a question is answered incorrectly. Each correct answer is awarded 5 points, while bonus questions are worth 10 points. The first player to reach 250 points wins.

name: Final Strategy
description:
"Final Strategy is an exciting, fast paced board game which challenges your ability to use offensive and defensive strategy. Armed with Troops, Captors and Bombs, you use your wits to dominate territory and capture opponents' Troops."

Printed in Canada. The only obvious connection to WWI is in the line-drawing graphics on the box. Box is identical in size to Mystery on the Nile.

110 Troops (36 maroon, 36 tan, 22 green, 16 blue) - Plastic cylinders
180 Barriers - White plastic T-shapes
4 Bunkers - Thick paperboard triangles meant to be folded to make screens
4 Bombs - White plastic 'mushrooms'
12 Captors - Blue plastic 'golf tees'

name: Donkey Kong Board Game
description: Japanese board game based on the Video Game character. Choose Donkey Kong or one of four relatives and explore the mysterious island collecting banana chips in order to buy cards used to battle your enemies. Make sure you accumulate enough power before your final face-off with King Koopa.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Roll / Spin and Move

name: The Archers
description:
Family game based on the British radio drama. Players compete to show their knowledge of the fictional village of Ambridge. Players take on the role of one of six characters and travel around the board gathering information from other players or acting out situations from the show.

Contents: Board showing the village of Ambridge, card deck, six character counters, timer, rulebook.
categories: Farming, Movies / TV / Radio theme, Trivia
mechanics: Acting, Dice Rolling, Role Playing, Roll / Spin and Move, Voting

name: Un-Uh! No, He Di'int!
description:
The game of secrets and laughter. This party game for girls includes spaces such as “Bad Boyfriend Bash”, “Do Something Silly”, and more.

The game includes a 12 ¼ in. x 7 ½ in. game board, a die, a Talk-About-It spinner, and 6 game markers.

name: Sensory
description:
A cloth bag is filled with a variety of differently shaped wooden pieces.

Players take turns to grab pairs of identical wooden pieces out of the bag. Once a player has his hand in the bag, he can feel for the pieces as he likes -without looking- and pick a pair, which he keeps if it matches, in which case he may continue to search for matching pairs. A turn lasts until the current player grabs two un-matching pieces or until a minute is up, whichever comes first.

Whoever has most pairs at the end of the game has won.

name: Bible Categories
description:
Quick! How fast can you name from the Bible . . .

. . . a river
. . . a plague
. . . a place where Paul preached
. . . a miracle involving food
. . . a descendant of Adam
. . . a story involving fish

. . . all using the letter "T" in your answer? And for extra points, can you name where your answer is recorded in the Bible? But, remember to be original! If your response is the same as an opponent's, you score nothing!

Whether you're a beginning Bible reader or an advanced Scripture scholar, you'll love playing Bible Categories! It's a fun and exciting way for family, friends, youth groups, or Sunday school classes to sharpen their Bible knowledge. And with 300 different categories, you'll never play the same game twice!

Curious as to which answer will win the game? Grab a group and play Bible Categories to find out! It's the fast-thinking Bible game that will leave you amazed at how much you already know and how much you can learn!

Includes: 25 Category Cards, 23 Letter Cards, 4 sets of Bible Categories scoring pads, 4 pencils, timer, and instruction sheet (including optional play suggestions for less challenging play, more challenging play, and play with people of varying degrees of Bible knowledge).

name: Dicecar
description:
From the publisher's web site:

This is Dicecar's Tri-Oval Speedway. Now available with either Dicecar Jr. rules and Extreme Dicecar rules packages.
Here’s the skinny of what Dicecar is. Dicecar is a Table Top Racing game that is played using dice and cards. The drivers must have their own 1/64th scale race cars. These are available at most department stores in the toy section or at your local racing collectible stores. Some spaces on the race track allow you lane changes or prompt you to draw cards which could be good or bad. Pit road is outlined in yellow, so you know where the speed limit begins. Strategies include pit stops in which you choose gas only, one side or both sides tire changes. Avoiding trouble and making moves which can put you in front of the competition are important strategies as well. To win you must be the first driver to cross the start/finish line after completing all of the laps and pit stops. Table Top Racing is no fantasy as you race face to face with your family and friends. Everyone can race at Dicecar. You don’t need to be a race fan to enjoy the game. Racing knowledge can help but it is not necessary. Experience counts, so race a few times as you develop your strategy. Dicecar includes qualifying, drafting, unscheduled pit stops for tire or engine trouble. Crashes can happen and the yellow flag will bring out the pace car for a caution. Have fun racing and building your 1/64th scale racing world. Different tracks are available as well as accessories like the high banks and soft walls. Other items such as the pace car, jet dryer trucks, tow trucks and ambulances are also available and make your world of Dicecar a lot of fun.

name: Elephants Never Forget: Memory Matching
description:
Box includes three different memory and matching games and a parent/teacher activity guide for teaching with the game. Pieces can be used to teach memory skills or matching sets of similar objects.

Ages 3 and up, 36 durable cards. Two-sided, colorful game mat. Game directions in English and Spanish. Activity guide (5.5in. x 8.5in.)

name: My First Matching Game
description: This beautifully illustrated matching game takes an innovative approach to teaching children the richness of the African American experience. Categories include: history, science, inventors, athletes, entertainers and culture. Game includes gameboard, 48 picture cards and a history booklet on each hero or cultural aspect featured. For Ages 3 to 6
categories: Card Game, Children's Game, Educational, Memory
publishers: Geebee Marketing, Inc., Pressman Toy Corp.

name: Beat The Bookie Race Odds Game
description:
A contemporary betting game consisting of 52 standard size playing cards:
8 horse cards and 44 odds cards


The rules description reads
"Given various odds the bookie chooses which horse will win
and the other players bet on what they think has been chosen.

The bookie then reveals the horse chosen and settles the bets accordingly. The objective of the game is to place bets on the horse the bookmaker picks."

name: The Sierra Club Game
description: In this game, billed as the first game endorsed by The Sierra Club, players move around a map of the Western Hemisphere placing Trailblazer Tokens and collecting Explorer's Chips in their log books. Movement cards feature information about animals and natural features of the Western Hemisphere. The first player to place all his tokens wins.
mechanics: Point to Point Movement, Set Collection, Tile Placement

name: Girls Night Out
description:
"Girls can get into enough mischief without any help from the likes of us but here's a pack of cards that will do just that. Over 50 new and outrageous dares that will have you dropping your inhibitions (or your knickers!)
So whether it's hen's night, birthday party or just messing around down the local, this pack of Girls Night Out cards is sure to make you weak with laughter and bring men to their knees...

She who dares sins"

This card game is a sequence of dares. Once a player completes a dare, she chooses who is to draw the next card. The player to complete the most dares in the evening is crowned Daredevil Queen of the Night.
categories: Card Game, Mature / Adult, Party Game

name: Palanoppa
description: Players are trying to find the right pieces for their jigsaw puzzles from the gameboard. After completing their jigsaw puzzles players also have to get back to square one first to win the game.

name: Het "Woord in Beeld" Spel
description: This is a game of building words formed by placing pictogram tiles on a board. First 29 tiles are drawn and placed on the board to form the pool from which the player can select tiles. As long as time allows, a player may draw tiles and place them on the edge of the board in order to form the longest possible word.
mechanics: Open Drafting, Pattern Recognition, Tile Placement

name: Tenacity
description: On an oval "400" meter Tenacity track, each player starts at the Hometown space and strives to end at the podium space where a roll of the die will determine which medal--gold, silver, bronze--they have won. Medals are included and must be placed around the winner's neck by the player on the right while others applaud and yell in support. Along the track there are sponsors, money and many miscellaneous gains and setbacks on the way to the winners' podium. Also included are clip-on athletes' passes and gold-colored metal playing pieces that represent different sports. Instructions, beside being on the inside of the box lid, are also included on a cassette tape.

name: Strike Force Jove
description:
Strike Force Jove (alternately Strike Force: Jove) is a game depicting a theoretical conflict between commercially backed mercenary forces within a region of the Jovian atmosphere. The game postulates the existence of a small area within Jupiter's atmosphere conducive to the creation of structurally primitive life-forms and highly complex chemicals which are commercially valuable in a variety of industrial processes.

It was published in Pandora magazine v1:2, and was a development from the author's Hellball game.

name: The New Teen Choices
description:
From the back of the box:

Making the right choice can be tough. But with the help of Teen Choices, learning to make the best decisions becomes exciting entertainment.

Grab your family and friends and get ready to come face to face with some of life's toughest decisions including those involving peer pressure, honesty, and purity. Learn how to base all your decision making on Biblical principles (twenty in all, supported by several versus from the popular NIV translation of the Bible

Includes gameboard, 6 player markers, 150 dilemma cards, 10 principle cards and instructions/reference booklet

name: Burger Party
description: Players are employees in a hamburger restaurant. They will have to take an order from one of the tables, put up the parts of the ordered meal and take it to the customer. The fastest waiter wins.
mechanics: Pick-up and Deliver, Roll / Spin and Move

name: Chicago Sports Trivia Game
description:
Chicago Sports Trivia contains 2,020 questions on 505 cards in 4 categories: Chicago Cubs, Chicago White Sox, Chicago Bears and All Sports (which includes Bulls, Black Hawks, Sting and college sports).

Players attempt to correctly answer as many questions as possible to be the first player to reach the WINNER box.

name: Skatterbug
description: Wind up a top and have it spin to knock as many discs in holes as possible to score different point values.

name: GrandSlam Baseball
description:
This is one of the games in the Tiny Tins series by Patch Products.

Players take turns batting and fielding as in real baseball. There are three decks of cards -- pitching, hitting, and fielding -- that determine what occurs in the game. The winner is the player with the most points after nine innings.

name: Overlords: 2-Player Box Set
description: This is a scaled-down introductory version of the larger Overlords game and can be combined with the larger game using Chaos Gates to cross back and forth. Comes with a 11" x 17" color map, 63 playing pieces, rule book, 5 Overlord cards, damage markers, around 150 cut-out units, 1D4, 1D6, 1D8, and 1D10.

name: Button Wars
description: Button Wars is a strategic table top tactical spaceship combat game. Players use button-like disks to represent various ships within a fleet and smaller plastic tokens to represent fighters and mech units, then take their fleet into battle against other players. The goal in each battle is to destroy as many ships as possible belonging to your enemies while losing a minimal number of ships yourself. This is basically a table top miniatures war game using buttons instead of miniatures. The main box is designed as a 2-player starter set. Players may add to their collection by purchasing additional button packs. The game comes with 8 Spaceship Buttons, 7 spaceship tokens, rule book, score pad, 1D4, ruler and game counters.

name: Das große Spiel um 15%
description:
Obviously produced at Ravensburger, as some of the components and the plastic box insert have the exact 1979 "Hare and Tortoise" form, this is a rather dull dice-driven game made from a publisher of German yellow press and TV magazines. Theme of the game (title translates to "The game around 15%") is the run of four advertising agencies "for 15%" of their customer's budget.

High-quality game components, but very little fun mainly coming from event cards like: "You have totally misunderstood the briefing, return to square one.".

name: Hullabaloo
description: This 1966 game from REMCO was based on the televison show of the same name that appeared from Apr 12, 1965 to April 11, 1966. The show featured a famous singer in the lead every week. People like Paul Anka, Bobby Vinton, Sammy Davis Jr., Petula Clark, Frankie Avalon and Annette Funicallo, Joey Hetherton, and The New Christy Minstrels sang the songs of the times. The first show featured Jack Jones singing "Hello Young Lovers" and ended 48 shows later with Paul Anka doing "What Now My Love". This game asked trivia questions that featured Pop Hits, Teen Culture, Stars and Dances .. called the Electric Teen Game .. includes 12 double sided cardboard 'Records' placed on a metallic 'Turntable' - questions printed on record cards are answered by using metal pointers to complete an electrical circuit and turn on a battery operated light bulb if correct .. these are not really playable records and the turntable doesn't really revolve .. question/answer subjects on 'records' include: Beatlemania, Musical Instruments, Solid Hits, Famous Singers, TV Stars, TV Shows, Faces in the Crowd, Mix & Match Mates, Broadway & Hollywood, Famous Parents, Swinging Groups, Famous Dances, Number Nonsense, Bits & Pieces, Home Towns, Common Folk, Song Titles Geography Go-Go and Million Record Sellers .. D

name: Trash is Cash! The Recycling Game
description: The object of this roll and move game is to obtain one million dollars by recycling the most materials and then being the first one to return to your garage (start). There is a large stack of cards for each of the following recyclables: glass, metal, paper, plastic&other. Cards contain recycling facts or questions and give financial rewards and penalties.

name: The Preventor
description:
From the back of the box:

NOW IT'S FUN TO LEARN!

America's exciting safety superhero teaches kids fire, water, and life safety by battling dangerous foes like Incendo. Now kids can learn life's safety lessons by playing the Preventor action game. Players venture into the Forest, Lakes, Suburbs, and the City, looking for the answers to Preventor's safety questions. It's an action packed game of adventure and survival, for 2-4 players grades K-6. Now it's fun to learn.
mechanics: Roll / Spin and Move, Set Collection

name: Pyöräytä vastaus
description: A game for couples. Pairs take a card that has a theme for a conversation or a mission. The pair has to reach an unanimous conclusion in the conversation or accomplish the mission. The most harmoniously acting couple wins the game.

name: Scoop 'em Up
description: Players compete to assemble ice cream cones from hands of colorful scoop-shaped cards, each depicting one of five ice cream flavors. Includes rules for four different game variants (two resemble war, two are rummy-like).

name: Complete Tiddledy Winks
description:
This is a deluxe version of Tiddeldy Winks with a bowling variant.

It can be played as the regular game in which players try to be the first to snap all three of their winks into the cup.

Or the Target Tiddeldy Winks variant can be played using the target board and cup, which are neatly set into the box bottom so that the cup is roughly flush with the target surface. In this variation the first player to 100 points wins, with higher points being achieved by the concentric rings of the target or the cup itself.

The Tiddeldy Winks Bowling game is what makes this unique. In this variation the target/cup remains in the box, but a cover is placed on the cup. Atop that cover sits a red bowling pin with a separate wide circular base. Nine white pins are placed on the marked circles around it, forming the ten pins of a standard triangular bowling arrangement.

Players try to snap their winks and down the pins. Ten points are awarded for the red pin, and one for each of the white pins. The player with the highest total after ten rounds of three winks snapped wins the game.

name: Wide World of Sports Tennis Game
description:
From the introduction to the rules:

"This fast-moving card game duplicates the strategy of the fast growing American sport. You try to outplay your opponent just as you would on a tennis court!"

The game consists of the following:

- A scoreboard
- 4 Pawns (2 yellow, 2 blue)
- A tennis court
- A spinner for service results
- 2 deck of cards (one deck for returns, one deck for shot types).

name: Walt Disney's Mary Poppins Game
description:
(From the instructions:)

OBJECT: To be the first player to race from Cherry Tree Lane to the Park.

BEFORE PLAYING: Assemble the merry-go-round selector as shown in the diagram.

Insert pole through figure holder and tighten into the base. Make sure the cutout figures are secure on the holder— Mary on one side, Bert on the other. Place selector on space provided on playing board.

To operate the selector, pick up the figure holder and let the pole slide all the way through. Place the base back on the circle and release the figure holder. It will spin to the bottom of the pole and spin to a stop. One pointer will point to one of the instructions surrounding the merry-go-round, the other will indicate a different instruction.

To determine order of play, each player picks a playing piece and puts it on one of the instructions around the merry-go-round. The figure holder is lifted and released and the player which Mary points to (or is nearest) goes first. Order of play is then clockwise from the playing piece of the first player.

All players now place their playing pieces on Cherry Tree Lane ready to start.

PLAY: Each player "asks Mary" for his instructions by using the merry-go-round selector as described earlier. The instructions Mary points to are then followed.

In moving around the board players follow any instructions given on the square where their playing piece lands.

If a player's piece lands on a sidewalk picture the selector is operated again by that player and he now "asks Bert."

If a playing piece lands on a carpet bag the player may, at his next turn, decide whether to advance directly to the next carpet bag or whether to "ask Mary." This choice exists for any player at any time his piece is on a carpet bag.

If a player lands on an umbrella he immediately "asks Mary" again.

The countryside counts as three squares if a player is passing through it. However, if a player chooses to be sent there by Mary or Bert he must miss his next two turns. (If a player waiting in the countryside trades places with a player in front or in back of him, he is free and the traded player must wait whatever turns remain.)

Winner is the first player to reach the park.
publishers: Alga, Edizioni Cicogna, Otto Maier Verlag, Whitman

name: Choices
description:
(from box back)

CHOICES transports players into the world of decision-making. It is an adventure of thought that begins with a dilemma and ends with a choice. Tucked in between is competition, verbal action, and a lot of guesswork.

Your family, friends, or Bible study group will find CHOICES to be a fun and challenging activity. They will come face-to-face with life and sometimes nose-to-nose with opposing views of it.

At the heart of CHOICES are twenty principles. They find their root in the Bible and focus on twenty issues of life. Each principle is supported by several verses from the NIV Translation of the Bible, both Old and New Testaments.

3 to 10 players can play, but 4 to 8 are best. CHOICES can also be played in teams, and is designed for ages teen to adult. Each game includes 170 Dilemma Cards, 20 Answer Cards, 10 Principle Cards, a plastic storage tray, and a reference booklet.

name: Nessie: An Aquatic Adventure
description: Nessie - An Aquatic Adventure was designed for the Loch Ness 2000 exhibition based on the shores of Loch Ness near Urquhart Castle.

name: Flag To Flag Racing
description:
A very straight-forward racing game. Players roll dice to move their cars around a track separated into spaces. Some spaces are cautions, at which a caution card is drawn. Players gain and lose money throughout the race and receive bonus money based on finishing positions. Multiple races can be played. The player with the most money at the end wins the game.

Components include board, custom money, caution cards, dice and playing piece cars.

The game looks to be self-published, with the box stating "Limited 1st Edition," and the rules stating that "You have purchased one of the original 2500 games produced." I doubt that there was a second run.

Rules also state: "Copyright No. VA249-950 Flag To Flag Racing Game. September 21, 1992" and "Made in North Carolina U.S.A."
publishers: Flag To Flag Racing Game Inc.

name: Whales
description:
Whales is a two player (or two team) game with a very simple dice rolling mechanic. Players will either play on the Toothed (red) whale team or the Baleen (yellow) whale team.

The playing board shows eight whales, four of each type. Upon the whales are several circles, with numbers ranging from 2 to 12 (2d6 possibilities). The teams take turns rolling two dice and placing red or yellow colored 'barnacles' upon available circles. On dice rolls of 5 or 10, the Special Cards deck is used. On dice rolls of doubles, another turn is taken.

The Special Cards deck contains cards with educational information on whales and an action, such as placing a barnacle in an available circle on one of your whales.

The round ends when one team has filled all four of their whales with barnacles. Points, bonuses and penalties are scored, then another round is begun. The game is played in several rounds until one side has scored the desired number of points.

name: Zehnkampf
description:
Zehnkampf (=Decathlon) is a dice game with very short rules. All 10 Decathlon events are decided by simple dice rolls, but the rules for the running events are a little more confusing and require some work in order to understand them.

The results of the 10 events are scored just like a real Decathlon. The result of this is, that some events have bigger point ranges than others, so it would be better to make an extra effort in these events... but since it's a simple dice game, there is no room to make extra efforts.

name: The New York City Trivia Game
description:
The New York City Trivia Game is a fun way to learn about the people, places, events, geography, public transportation, museums, theaters, sports, stores, restaurants and media that make New York City so great.

NYTG will appeal to New York natives and one-time visitors alike. The City encompasses cultures and traditions the world over, so whether you play NYTG to test how much you already know or simply to learn more, you're sure to have a great time celebrating the diversity of New York City. [Excerpt from game introduction]

Move down the island of Manhattan, starting in Harlem and ending at the Statue of Liberty, answering questions in any one of four categories: Landmarks and History; Street Smarts; Arts, Entertainment and Sports; and Shopping, Eating and Media. NYTG will test and expand your knowledge about New York City. [Excerpt from game back of game box]

name: Amelie, aufgepasst!
description:
Help your 3 little ants find their way to their nest. Avoid the holes near the path where you can hide (get out of the game) from your enemies, which are mixed with good characters in some memory cards. So you have a good chance to stay on the right path.
A game which comes with rules in 8 languages (D,USA,F,E,P,J,NL,I)
mechanics: Memory, Race, Roll / Spin and Move

name: LEGO Playground
description:
From the box back:

Kids love playgrounds - an they love counting, too! In this clever preschool counting game, players travel around the colorful paths in search of LEGO bricks. Each LEGO brings players one step closer to reaching the tree house - winning the game!

Along the way, they may get to play hopscotch, which gives them an extra turn. Look out for the sandbox - land in it, and you'll lose a turn!

Three levels of play make this a game for even the youngest players.
categories: Children's Game, Educational, Math, Number, Racing

name: Madman The Game!
description:
A boardgame built on the manic humor of Mike Allred's Madman!
A simple roll and move game that was free in an issue of Wizard in 1995. Contents are a board and counters. Player must supply dice.
categories: Comic Book / Strip, Dice, Humor, Party Game

name: Wild-West
description:
This game was issued in 1979 to celebrate the 75th year jubilee of Vedes, "the leading trade group for games and leisure in Europe".

It's a commemorative issue of a Ravensburger game from 1904. The board shows several scene in the old west and included are 6 tin figures like in the original, 3 showing Cowboys and 3 showing red Indians.

The game itself is a simple dice game like many games of that period. The only remarkable thing is, that 2 special spaces don't let you do something on your own, but let you wait for neighbors throwing a certain number with the die.

name: Jurassic Dinosaurs
description:
Summary from the box:
The race is on! Can you escape the volcano and reach safety evading the Tyrannosaurus Rex as it stalks across the board and without falling prey for the many other prehistoric pitfalls as you go. Good Luck!
A monster game for 2-4 players aged 6-adult

Game description:
The game is a simple children's game similar to snakes and ladders but with the added twist of a T-Rex. The board has a linear path where players all start from a common starting point and move towards a common ending point. Along the way there are special spots where the player can move forward / backward automatically (ala snakes and ladders), miss a turn, throw again, or cause the T-Rex to move.
The T-Rex twist involves a T-Rex token that starts somewhere in the middle of the board. A player rolls his die and moves the number of spaces as indicated on the die (again just like snakes and ladders). He then moves the T-Rex backwards or forwards the same number of squares as he wishes. If the T-Rex is moved to the same spot as another player, that player falls back 12 spaces.
In this way, turn by turn, players try to advance to the end while at the same time try to use the T-Rex to stomp on their opponents and make them fall back.
The first player who reaches the end wins the game.

name: Bingo Party
description:
Taken from the box: "Eyes down for a new way to play Bingo - on DVD. Its easy! All you need is the remote control.
